plugins/modules/identity_user_info.py.message: worth to print "domain" in this case

nice, I think in this case we need to remove 'enabled' from filters?
like: filters['is_enabled'] = filters.pop('enabled')
so it's not passed together with is_enabled to query
I can do that. Wasn't sure if I needed to get rid of it.

it can be one line:
  filters['is_enabled'] = filters.pop('enabled')

now when you have defaults, you can have just
  filters = self.params['filters']
is it the only difference between old and new?
In my experiments, both 'enabled' and 'is_enabled' work with OpenStack SDK 0.36.5 and later when passed to self.conn.identity.users(). So why drop it?
You're correct, I dropped the conditional. Not sure why I was under the wrong impression here.

As you know I do worry a lot about backward compatibility. But in this case it is fine and actually good to break it. Why? Because the results returned from the SDK have changed (e.g. enabled => is_enabled). With renaming from openstack_users to users, existing code will more likely break and thus it will be easier for our users to see that something has changed.
I'd love to, but I'm concerned about breaking compatibility too much. I also left it for consistency's sake, most of these info modules return a openstack_$RESOURCE list already.
can be empty, cannot be null.

Please do pass domain_id to users only if it has a value. Atm if domain is not specified by the user, then domain will be None and thus the OpenStack SDK will be called with http://***/identity/v3/users?domain_id=None instead of http://***/identity/v3/users.

One way to solve it would be to replace

  domain = dom_obj.id

with

  filters["domain_id"] = dom_obj.id

or something like that.

The standard way to describe this is as a 'temporary' volume (see, for example, [0]).  Please s/temporal/temporary/ here and throughout to avoid confusion.

[0] https://docs.python.org/3/library/tempfile.html
Done

:-1: Would you please explain in what scenarios this could happen?
Do you have any steps to reproduce this issue?
I think it's best to create a bug case to track this issue, but I'll let others have their say as well.

This can happen for example if we are creating a backup from a snapshot and then delete the temporary volume that is being used to do the actual backup.

I agree that we need a bug created in launchpad, to have the reference added to this commit message:

  Closes-Bug: #1234

And then have a release note explaining what has been fixed, as mentioned here: https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html
Done

cinder/volume/driver.py.message: This sounds like a method that is useful for things other than just backup -- with this change, we should really also rename this to something like "_create_temp_cloned_volume_for_backup".  This would make it clear what this method does and when it is useful.
No. I'm going to keep the methods generic in the patch set 2 instead of specializing them for backup because I noticed create_temp_volume_from_snapshot() is used for backup and revert to snapshot.
This comment haven't been addressed yet. Are we going to create a new method for this?
This method is used for backing up and reverting snapshot. This cannot be renamed only for backup.

:nit: 
For the sake of consistency, i think the method name should keep the underscore.
Unless we need to keep the driver interface consistent for out-of-tree drivers, I would like to rename this method to clarify that this method is called from outside of this class.

nit: I think it would be best to do the same thing that it is being done to "_create_temp_volume_from_snapshot".  Basically keeping the current name, changing the method to accept a status value (for example with the default of 'available') and then passing the fields.VolumeStatus.BACKING_UP status on this call.
I prefer to go with the suggestion from comment on L1234, but if we don't do that, we should use fields.VolumeStatus.BACKING_UP here instead

As far as I know (I am not familiar with temporary volumes), temporary volumes are created from a snapshot and then used to copy data to the destination volume. So I agree that temporary volumes should have 'in-use' status from the beginning.
I think we are going for 'backing-up' status instead of 'in-use' to be more specific.

designate/worker/tasks/base.py.message: Can you provide some background here, if the action your passing is the current zone.action would that be a problem, or in the case of an UPDATE action are you going to stack these together into a single zone transfer , for example? And in the case of a delete, if the zone.action is currently in an UPDATE, I'm assuming you wait until its complete before issuing the delete task?
So looking in the database enum for the actions, for some wacky reason there is a "NONE". I would guess we don't want to cancel the retries on a valid action if the DB goes to NONE right?
Great question. NONE basically means that there is nothing to do. Hmm. Let me think about this.

So NONE pretty much means that the "previous" action was completed successfully.
https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/central/service.py#L2411

Since all actions to the worker originate from central, it should be safe to assume that if action is NONE (or DELETE) the currently pending options have all been successful, since the serial is checked in central.

The issue here is primarily if you create a zone and instantly delete it. The worker logic (NOTIFY) will get stuck retrying because the zone is gone. This causes a ton of unnecessary log spam. Another issue is if you create or update a record and then delete the zone the same thing will happen. Since the zone is gone there is nothing to update.

We could probably make this code safer by only stopping when the zone has already been deleted, but I believe that we cannot go from action CREATE to UPDATE without the zone first being successfully completed. We should verify that though.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
>I'm unconvinced it's worth it when we could just fetch the tarball of it and unpack that, or pull it all from Git as described in the debian/README.source file, and then overwrite it with whatever files we need to change.

I guess the idea was to make it a bit clearer in review what's changing.  initially yes this is bigger, but from now on we either import our specific change, or can manually pull the upstream and just propose a diff update to what's in here, and we can see specifically the updates pretty clearly.  as opposed to having either diffs against files checked in, or munging scripts, or copies of random-looking files

like when we add a patch, we have to add the diff and update the series in the right place.  if we wanted to replace an upstream patch, we'd have to delete the upstream diff, fiddle the series file, add ours, fiddle the series file, etc.  as opposed to just committing it in a clear change.

on your side -- this is moot right now, when there's no diffs for us, and few upstream patches anyway.  i would generally say that maintenance upstream seems to be much more active with things than a few years ago (meaning we are less likely to *have* to do major surgery here anyway).  but I can't shake the feeling that this situation has happened before.

 > As for the job repository, would this make more sense in opendev/system-config? I know the idea was to not put it in a trusted config repo, which rules out openstack/project-config, but openstack//openstack-zuul-jobs is mostly OpenStack-specific versions of things while this is meant to be a general OpenDev process. I'm not strongly opposed though.
 
> For that matter, is there a good reason to be adding this to the openstack tenant rather than the opendev tenant?

For both of these, it was just to be alongside the rpm generation path.

rpm uses the standard afs publishing jobs, and the system-config roles are looking for the output files in tarballs.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs; so moving it does take some coordination work.

my preference is to keep the jobs together, which is why i started here

i'm not opposed to system-config if we agree.  or a new opendev/openafs-deb-ppa repo if we'd prefer to keep it separate?

One inline thing to help me out (and possibly others). But also I wonder if openstack-zuul-jobs is the best location for this job? OpenDev is using these openafs packages in its control plane. Maybe it should go in opendev/system-config or opendev/project-config? I'm not too picky about it if we want to keep it here close to the wheel builds.
Sounds like this repo location is intentional. The followup change addresses my concerns with knowing what the upstream is and where to check deltas.

i'm definitely willing to reorganize this, but it's a bit moot until it actually does something; which it doesn't at the moment because we need to promote it in the post pipeline to actually build anything; which i can't do speculatively.  i'm going to go with this so i can work on that (pushing to a non-active ppa) and then, once it works, before we switch production i'll loop back and see how we feel

glance_store/tests/unit/test_cinder_base.message:
I don't really like testing that methods were called, and called with the right arguments, even though it is very often the easiest way. Here, I think we could do:

test_str = 'test_str'
expected = '9c02dd5524a5585746ff970192b4862fdd957dd024449f8e79135be3f3e91f39'
self.assertEqual(cinder.hashlib.sha256(test_str.encode('utf-8')), expected)

This way we would do a "black box" testing of _get_hash_str. WDYT?
Yeah, I'm really not sure what the problem is here. We mock libraries all the time to make sure we call them properly. This seems totally okay to me.

The purpose of this test is to verify if hashlib.sha256 is called with the string we pass to "get_hash_str" (in utf-8 encoded form).
The test you proposed is more of checking if hashlib is calculating the hash correctly which is beyond the purpose of this test since it's a python lib and we don't account for if it's working correctly or not. Also we try to mock out external dependencies in unit tests which in this case is hashlib.
I don't mind adding your proposed test but i still think we're testing the right thing here irrespective of if it looks easy or complex.
Let me know if you would still like the new test to be added and I will update in next PS.

I think both the checks serves the purpose here but somehow I think rajat is right about mocking third party library here. Cyril please let me know if you thinks otherwise.

Thank you!

check-rdo - Both RDO jobs failed, for different reasons. None of the errors look related to this change.

I believe the reason for the failure is that the UC was not updated with this patch. This patch enable the dns_domain_port extension in neutron, which is required to set the dns_name attribute on ports.

Step 1: Apply patch to THT

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: just to make sure: let's say we're building some pools/keys at this stage ... should we update this list during the overcloud deployment if new CephPools are added?

> just to make sure: let's say we're building some pools/keys at this stage ... should we update this list during the overcloud deployment if new CephPools are added?

Yes, let's talk about that more here.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/837998/1/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/templates/deployed_ceph.yaml.j2#13

For the purposes of the tripleo-client change this line basically produces 

"profile rbd pool=vms, profile rbd pool=volumes, profile rbd pool=images"

If it's passed something like

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/838003/2/deploy-guide/source/features/deployed_ceph.rst#974

If someone re-runs 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy' with tripleo_cephadm_pools updated, then the cephx key will be updated to include all of the pools and the new pools will be idempotently created. 

So I think the initial creation under 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy' is fine, but we should talk more about how it's passed to Heat in

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/837998/1/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/templates/deployed_ceph.yaml.j2#13

We need to be careful when the overcloud deploy cmd is built because the order of the redefinition of these variables (especially pools and keys) might cause unexpected behaviors or failures during the overcloud deployment.

Maybe this is just a topic we should highlight in the documentation change

I share your concern here. Let's talk about the full cycle and see if there would be any issues. 

- User follows [1] and vms, volumes, images pools are created. Assume they used the same names as the defaults for CinderRbdPoolName, GlanceRbdPoolName, NovaRbdPoolName because we will them to in the doc. But we can't enforce this and overrides for CinderRbdPoolName, GlanceRbdPoolName, NovaRbdPoolName are not in this template.

- During overcloud deploy, CephPools is overridden by this line [2]

- CephPools will behave like extra_pools [3]

- We are already encourage overriding CephPools because the PG numbers are rarely all the same [4] so I don't think that will be a problem. Even if they use it on stack updates to add extra pools.

- Because we overrode the client username and key [5], calls to the ceph_key module  will be idempotent.

- RGW pools are created automatically by RGW and not on the THT layer. Manila pools are handled by a different variable on the THT layer [6].

So the RBD pools should be OK via CephPools based on my understanding, though we need to test it to be sure.


[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/838003/2/deploy-guide/source/features/deployed_ceph.rst#979

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/837998/1/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/templates/deployed_ceph.yaml.j2#13

[3] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/cephadm/ceph-base.yaml#L610

[4] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/ceph_config.html#customize-ceph-placement-groups-per-openstack-pool

[5] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/cephadm/ceph-base.yaml#L617-L620

[6] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/cephadm/ceph-base.yaml#L612-L616

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message:
We shouldn't have to make any changes here in ansible to handle the transition to fluxcd based apps.

The intent is to just deliver a new version of the bootstrap apps using the same versioning methodology. The difference will be that the new version delivered in stx.7.0 will have different content (a FluxCD app).

The framework should be able to determine based on app content if it's a FluxCD or an Armada app.

If we are ready to replace the Armada apps for nginx/cert-mgr, then I recommend one of the following:

1) Drop the armada app from the package build and drop the -fluxcd from the fluxcd app name. This will install an app tarball for bootstrap that should just be a version increment but have FluxCD content

2) If you really want to keep the Armada version around (maybe needed for application rollback) then add -armada to the armada app, and drop the -fluxcd from the fluxcd app name. This will install an app tarball for bootstrap that should just be an version increment but have FluxCD content

With either option we shouldn't need any special handling.

cinder/values.yaml.message:
i'm having troubles reconciling this structure with values_overrides. what is "group:"?

how would you grant access to more than one project in the same domain?

isn't that a duplicate key? i think in this case probably only projectB would get access.

(yes, ignore the previous comments about the pre-existing stuff, although it might be nice to cleanup.)

This is a good point. What do you think about:
grant_access:
  domainA:
    - projectA
    - projectB
  domainB:
    - projectC
    - projectD

I'm just looking at the duplicated map keys in the YAML, which are not allowed by the YAML spec. The way Helm handles it, I believe that the second value with key 'mydomain' will overwrite the first.

These two end up being effectively the same:

  grant_access:
    mydomain: projectA
    mydomain: projectB

  grant_access:
    mydomain: projectB

Not really. This is translated into:
openstack volume type set --project-domain mydomain --project projectA
openstack volume type set --project-domain mydomain --project projectB
and finally will be represented as:
<...>
| access_project_ids | 1d77622a9e1748569f1969f6e1c1c5f3, 5a84e6ac41f74dacab1a3c69fa748d80 |
<...>
The domain part allows us to identify the project ID even if two different domains have a project with the same name (which is impossible by default since Pike I believe) But if we are using the name instead of ID, this is a recommended practice to provide a domain.

group was merged previously: https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/src/branch/master/cinder/values.yaml#L369
Simply didn't touch it.

For different projects inside the same domain the structure is the same:
grant_access:
  mydomain: projectA
  mydomain: projectB

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I performed the following test:
- deployed focal-victoria env using cs:mysql-router-6 and no cluster-name
- upgraded cinder-mysql-router from rev6 to cs:mysql-router-8, no errors
- redeployed same env using cs:mysql-router-6 and "myCluster" custom name
- upgraded cinder-mysql-router from rev6 to cs:mysql-router-8, hook error as reported in LP
- tested upgrading glance-mysql-router from rev6 to ch:mysql-router latest/edge directly. Resulted in "Error connecting to MySQL"
- tested upgrading keystone-mysql-router from rev6 to master code + this fix. Resulted in "Error connecting to MySQL"
- Upon inspecting keystone-mysql-router and comparing to placement-mysql-router running rev6, I found out that in keystone-mysql-router the mysqlrouter process was not running, despite the systemd service state is "exited" in both units (placement and keystone). I restarted the keystone-mysql-router systemd service and the mysqlrouter process appeared, and charm status cleared up
- Tried to restart the glance-mysql-router service, but the systemd service would fail to be restarted. Upon inspecting /var/lib/mysql/glance-mysql-router/mysqlrouter.conf I saw the jujuCluster config block. Erased it and the systemd service could be restarted successfully, but the update-status hook overwrites the file adding back the jujuCluster config block and crashing the systemd service. If the file is set to immutable, the hook fails.

Conclusion:
- this fix works, but it seems something is causing this need of restart of the mysql-router service manually

I retested the upgrade scenario with default cluster name from charmstore rev6 to latest/edge rev22 just to confirm whether I would hit the "need for service restart bug" being unrelated to this patch. Indeed I hit the issue, so this is a current bug on master and unrelated to this fix.
LGTM.

.zuul.yaml.message: expected a list for dictionary value @ data['promote']['jobs'][6]['infra-prod-manage-nameservers']['files']
expected a list for dictionary value @ data['promote']['jobs'][6]['infra-prod-manage-nameservers']['files']

I appreciate the opportunity to make the OpenDev sysadmins not be a bottleneck on approving DNS changes as long as we continue to rely on thorough testing to avoid breaking the service. Option #2 or the option of only running it from the config repo using secrets rather than having access to ssh keys are also okay by me.
I think this challenge supports my position that we should retain OpenDev sysadmin control over BIND zone repos.

The best options I have for this are:
1) We say that opendev needs to have exclusive control of the zonefile repos, and we add their keys.
2) We add a feature to zuul where if we set final: True and allowed-projects: foo, then if the job is used in one of the allowed-projects, the ssh key from the repo where it is defined is added to the set.  I.e, the zonefile repos get to "borrow" the system-config key, just for this job.
I think we can do #1 for now and work on implementing #2 later.

This shouldn't have zuul in the name; this should be: "service-nameserver.yaml" which already exists.  I think we can go ahead and drop service-nameserver from run_all.sh as part of this patch too, but we should stage patches to add this to the data repos so we merge them quickly to close the gap.

Fun fact: any job can trigger this repo, but we've only added the ssh keys for system-config and project-config to bridge.  That means that if we add this to a zone repo, we will need to add that zone repo's key to bridge (which means that the people with approval powers on the zone repo could run any command on bridge).
I believe I have the opinion that opendev should own bind zone repos.
We could move this into the job definition (and as for the data repos, we can either override it when setting it in the pipeline, or we could add the entries the other repos would need to this one).

Adding my understanding first.

We are going to create new API /export or modify /file (download api) which will create a new gzip file containing image data, image metadata and some footer (magic number) to indicate that metadata is included in file.
The newly created file will be stored on client machine so that it can be moved by air gapped systems (like usb) or used as an input to another import for image creation request in another deployment.

Based on above understanding, I have few questions;
 
1. This spec only talks about how the export (.gzip) file is created but it does not include how it will be read by the glance as it is mentioned that these efforts will be tracked separately (as discussed in PTG).

2. IMO all should be part of the same spec as if we don't have provision to read this new file and act on it then it will be just a file sitting on local machine and of no use.

3. Even though this is a draft and not the final design I think we should basically have a primary solution and others could be alternative, like adding new /export endpoint should be primary solution.

4. If we considering to modify /file endpoint (download API) then how it will know that it has to include the metadata should be included in the spec.

5. Property protection, what if user has a permission to read/view the property at one deployment but he is forbidden from creating it using property protection. As defined in spec as he is able to see the property the property will be included in the .gzip file as a metadata and will be created on target glance as well (does this violates property protection here).

6. There are certain read only and reserved properties (starting with os_glance_) which user might be able to see but not able to create those, so are we going to copy/store those properties as well?

7. I think we should have a potential/important list of metadata property defined in the spec that should be included in the output.

8. What if decompression plugin is not enabled at the target glance?

9. Can't we use the file generated by this proposal using /data (upload) api?

Even it is a draft, adding -1 so that it will get attention in review list of others.
Thank you for proposing the idea.
Functionality would be useful; comment inline about an alternative to consider.

There is no owner for this, so I assume this is just documenting something we could do, but with no specific schedule for this cycle right?

I like this idea in general, and the fact that it's a useful thing helps lend support to the glance-download case for importing metadata, as the mere existence of this feature proposal clearly indicates how important it is to bring metadata along with the image.

I definitely think that we should strive to avoid creating any new sort of format, especially when things like tar exist specifically for things like this. It would be trivial to provide the desired compatibility with older glances with something like "glance image-export $img | tar x justtheimage.img | glance image-create --file -".

Otherwise, agree with Abhi regarding adding more detail here about consumption and the full workflow. I definitely think that this should be a new /export API and not just /file with a magic header.
also zuul will report -1 as it is missing the index file.

specs/zed/approved/glance/image-export.r.message:
This seems to be describing the creation of a bespoke file format to effectively contain two files. IMHO, we should avoid doing that any time it's not strictly necessary.

The tar format was designed with the specific purpose in life of being able to be generated on the fly and contain multiple files. Similarly, gzip is often used to wrap files and can be done on the fly as well. I would expect the ideal solution here would be to stream a gzip'd tar file containing the data as a file, followed by the metadata as a file, in json text format. That way it's easy to examine both manually as needed, and is useful as a general-purpose backup format.

Both import and upload would be able to parse and split these formats on the fly.

Yep, OVA/OVF would be better as well, I'm just not sure it's worth trying to adhere to the standard. Given what we want it for - we don't want to store it as an OVA, but rather unpack it back into its constituent parts. I think that runs counter to glance's reason for "supporting" OVA currently, which is to provide the OVA as-is to a hypervisor that wants it.

But, definitely agree that using some existing multi-file stream encoding is most important, and structure within that is less so. If it makes sense to try to be an OVA, then that's cool too.

Glance already claims to support 'ova' container format, which is a single tarfile distribution of an OVF, which is roughly data files + a manifest describing the data.  This seems exactly what we would want, the image file + image metadata in the manifest.

I don't think we want to create our own custom file format unless absolutely necessary.  The downside of OVF is that I think the manifest is supposed to be XML, but we could probably get around that by having a <image-json>{dump of image-detail response}</image-json> element.

Anyway, it's another thing to consider in the Alternatives section.
If it's a tar file, then it's easy to split the raw image out before uploading, either manually or in a pipe.
This will be re-usable for the glance-download case, so we should make sure that whichever of these efforts go first, the extraction routine(s) are written in such a way that they can be consistent.

If I understand correctly the thing the reverted change broke is the ability for users to continue using predictable interface names outside of bullseye. Predictable interface names are desirable for a number of reasons as outlined in the systemd docs [0]. Considering that predictable names are desirable and we've broken dhcp-all-interface users ability to opt into them I think a revert is still appropriate.

That said we should also try to continue to support users on bullseye with dhcp-all-interfaces. I strongly suspect that udev triggering on move events will address the problems simply because we had similar issues with centos 9 and that addressed it. To test this I've pushed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/839079 to try and confirm bullseye doesn't work with this revert, then an update to add |move in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/839080 to see if that corrects it. It would also be helpful for ironic to depends on 839080 to check if this also works for them. I don't know what code base needs that done to it to check.

If however, the |move doesn't fix things then we should decide if we are debugging this further or we can just make predictable device names optional. If we do make them optional we should probably use one of the disabling methods indicated in the systemd docs [0] rather than nuking this specific udev file. That way we are using expected interfaces for this behavior toggle.

[0] https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames/

It's already filtered out as "censored" before the result is passed in here.  But, I haven't proved that to myself, hence not reverting this.  This seems totally free-form as to what any plugin may return here, so we'll always have some variation...

I've proposed a test in the follow-on Ib0d2360f98daf33e05207c9c285528ce2f51cbf9.  I think that will help we don't regress here, if we do fiddle things.

So I can no longer get Ansible actually into this code path; empirically, v2_runner_on_ok does not actually receive anything it should not log.  even something like

 - name: loopit
   foo:
    bar: 'arg'
   no_log: '{{ item }}'
   loop:
     - true
     - false

will be censored; for the above v2_runner_on_ok just receives a result._result value of

 {'censored': '...', changed: False}

(I belive this is https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/bda074d34e46ee9862a48ed067ad42260d3f92ab -- task is no_log if any item is)

The fact that we could get here at all was the original bug, since fixed in Ansible.  I would propose removing this, but that will involve getting 3 people (including myself) to all read through the ansible changes and convince themselves that we can indeed no longer get here.  It's not an API as such, there's no documentation on what is being passed in (I can find).  So that's why I left it as the "abundance of caution" comment ...

So I can't really get this path tested, because you can't hit it?

Right, my concern is that the code we are fixing "failed safe" in cases where it didn't understand the input. But now we can get an unexpected type and then echo the information that was meant to not be logged. I've left a suggestion on the child change for improving the test to try and cover this specific thing.

What we can test is that we don't leak the information. Whether or not we enter this block is somewhat orthogonal to checking that. Can we update the test to check that in a no_log task with strings instead of dicts we don't leak the strings?

It is the ID of the private gpg key in aptly cntainer. Each time when client want to deploy a repo and sign it, it has to tell aptly the gpg key ID and related password: SIGN_KEY and SIGN_PASSWD. Seems we can't configure it, that is the way aptly used to sign the repository throug REST api.

I'm bothered by hard-coding this, maybe it should be configurable somehow?

No, the key is installed in server side, here is container repomgr(aptly). 
There can be many private keys in server. In deploy stage, here, client just request the server to deploy and sign a repository with specified key and password. In server side, aptly will make firstly deploy the repository, then sign the Release file with that very kay and password. Aptly itself doest store the password of thoes keys, so we(client) have to send to it each time we use the key.

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: Just stating my personal opinion here, these type of formatting changes that are unrelated to the main functionality that the patch is intending to address increases reviewers efforts to check if these changes doesn't introduce a regression. IMO we shouldn't be doing these type of changes and keep them for a separate refactoring effort.

I'd normally be inclined to agree, but in this case I wasn't actually making these changes: black was. I was breaking a lot of formatting during this refactor and rather than manually fix these, I was running each modified function through black. This had the unfortunate side effect of introducing some unnecessary changes but given the time it saved me (this effort already took _days_ to write and test), it seemed a fair thing to do. A possible alternative would have been to get things black-ready before I started making changes, but I've done that before and not everyone has liked it (e.g. see Gorka's comment on [1]). Rock, meet hard place 😄 Hopefully you can understand my desire to avoid incurring unnecessary work even if it made the review experience slightly worse...

As an aside, I did tell Brian that I was using black to avoid having to manually fix formatting in another review so this isn't the first time I've encountered this. I definitely could have been clearer and called it out in the commit messages.

As another aside, perhaps there's a willingness in Cinder to run black over the codebase like Django did recently [2]. There would be short term backport pain, but it'd make these large scale refactors so much easier in the future. You could avoid breaking git blame using a '.git-blame-ignore-revs' file [3]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/813219
[2] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=30258530
[3] https://michaelheap.com/git-ignore-rev/
Ack, Personally i don't like some of black's formatting choices but i will make sure to not flag them again in the series.

No, 'context.session' will always be set in this method because the method is decorated with the engine facade context manager ('main_context_manager.writer'). The only reason we need it in 'model_query' is because that method is still being called by some methods that do not have this decorator. This is the same for any other method that has multiple callers and is the reason I added TODOs for myself in [1]. As soon as all callers of 'model_query' have this decorator, we can remove the logic from 'model_query' and rely on 'context.session' being set. I do that in effectively the last patch of the series at [2]

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This wasn't as clear as it should have been. You'll note that through the rest of this series, I'm attempting to make each commit change all functions related to a particular model (DB table). The methods I've marked up here do not match that pattern. The reason for this is because they're not used directly. Rather, they're used by "generic" methods that handle multiple different models. For example, '_volume_get_query' is used by '_generate_paginate_query' (via 'PAGINATION_HELPERS'), but that method is a generic method also works with 'Snapshot' model entries (via '_snapshot_get_query'), 'VolumeType' model entries (via '_volume_type_get_query') etc. I found myself erroneously modifying methods like '_volume_get_query' when modifying other 'Volume' model-related methods, which then caused errors for things like '_generate_paginate_query' since the signature of '_volume_get_query' was different to e.g. '_snapshot_get_query'. I stuck in this precursor commit to stop myself making this mistake consistently 😅 They'll all be converted at the end of the series, don't worry!

But made it more specific whild doing some debugging (it cause it was cause by a falsey problem), which turned out this wasn't the cause.. but forgot to turn it back.. I guess is doens't jurt to be specific 😊
So, why even avoid instantiating the RingData in the first place?

Because as soon as it becomes a RingData object the replica_count that was stored in the metadata is thrown away and becomes a property that checks the replica2part2dev table. When only loading with `metadata_only=True` the replica2part2dev table isn't deserialized so the replica_count will be 0 (even though it isn't).

An old pickle ring, will always also have the r2p2d table so we can just call the property.

I'll have a play and see if I can come up with something better.
Seems much better just to not throw away the serialised replica_count and use it if the r2p2d table isn't loaded. That's what the new patchset does.
I guess a new replica and handoff replicating to it could still have a smaller number though. But at least tightens this edgecase window.

Might want to run replicators on primaries, then run updaters on primaries. Otherwise I worry that we might have an object PUT that can update some but not all primaries, and it just so happens that brain.node_numbers[0] was the one that missed it. In that case, it'd send its update, receive some more rows via replication, and race with the handoff to update again on L116.
kk, swapping these is simple enough 😊

Part of me wants to just stop issuing updates from handoffs... we never expect them to have a complete picture of what's going on in a container...

Would still have to worry about the rebalance scenario, though, where a PUT makes an empty DB on a primary until replication has a chance to rsync-then-merge over it. I think there'd be an opportunity for the empty DB to send an update and throw off stats before replication.
But if it hasn't been rsync_then_merged then it wont have any incoming_syncs right, so it wont update. That's how the current patchset works.

*Ever* having this happen isn't great -- it's one thing to be eventually consistent, but quite another to have an accurate state that then *goes backwards in time*. It feels a decent bit like that bug we had in sharding where a failure to get a shard would mean we'd just skip that section of the namespace...

the reported_* fields aren't replicated. If they were then a primary would get the handoff's reported_object_count of zero and subsequently update the root again with the 'correct' value. But replicating reported_* timestamps might also result in primaries sending more updates after replicating with other primaries. I'm not sure if that is a bad thing though.
